item.title: Learning Kubernetes Controllers
item.description: Kubernetes' extensibility is probably its biggest strength. Controllers and CRDs are all over the place. But finding the right information to begin writing a controller isn't easy due to the sheer amount of tribal knowledge scattered everywhere. Here are some links to help you start.

item.title: Resources for learning how to write Kubernetes controllers
How do packets find their way back?
item.description: In one of my previous posts, I studied how traffic flows when using Kubernetes Services. While drawing the last diagram, I did not clearly see how traffic could make its way back to the user. In this post, I focus on how packets find their way back and what makes stateless rewritting interesting.

item.description: Here is what my home office looks like in 2020 and what changed between 2019 and 2020!

item.title: Migrating from GKE to Civo's K3s
item.description: My free trial on GKE was ending in 2 days and I had to find a way to migrate away. I decided to switch to Civo's managed K3s.

item.title: The Packet's-Eye View of a Kubernetes Service
item.description: The Service and Ingress respectively brings L4 and L7 traffics to your pods. In this article, I focus on how traffic flows in and what are the interactions between the ingress controller and the "service-lb controller" (the thing that creates the external load balancer). I also detail how the `hostPort` approach shapes traffic.

item.title: You should write comments
item.description: We often talk about avoiding unecessary comments that needlessly paraphrase what the code does. In this article, I gathered some thoughts about why writing comments is as important as writing the code itself.

item.title: Debugging Kubernetes Networking: my kube-dns is not working!
item.description: Some pods were unable to connect to the kube-proxy pod on one of my GKE Kubernetes clusters. This post present an in-depth investigation using tcpdump, wireshark and iptables tracing.

item.title: Avoid GKE's expensive load balancer by using hostPort
item.description: I want to avoid using the expensive Google Network Load Balancer and instead do the load balancing in-cluster using akrobateo, which acts as a LoadBalancer controller.

item.title: What to do when Go ignores HTTP_PROXY for 127.0.0.1
item.description: At some point, the Go team chose to disable the proxy for requests coming from localhost or 127.0.0.1. This is annoying when debugging services locally.

item.title: Go Happy Path: the Unindented Line of Sight
item.description: Readability is a property we all love about Go. In other languages, it might be fine to have a lot of nested if statements; in Go, it is a good practice to keep away from overly-nested logic.

item.title: GO111MODULE is everywhere: history and tips
item.description: GO111MODULE is all over the place. It appears in README install instructions, in Dockerfiles, in makefiles. On top of that, the behavior of GO111MODULE has changed from Go 1.11 to 1.12, changed again with 1.13 and will changed a last time in 1.14.

item.title: Use of conditions in Kubernetes controllers
item.description: Although progress is being made, Kubernetes controllers and operators still require prior knowledge about Kubernetes internals. Information on how to set the status is scattered across comments, issues, PRs and the Kubernetes code itself. Conditions may be a good solution for your controller, but for what?
